visualization.title: How We Visualize This Planet
visualization.intro: Our planet visualizations are generated procedurally using real scientific data from NASA's Exoplanet Archive. Here's how different properties influence what you see:

density.title: Density
density.description: Determines surface texture and composition. High-density worlds appear more rugged with retained impact craters (strong gravity holds surface features). Low-density "puffy" planets have smoother, more volatile-rich appearances.

insolation.title: Insolation Flux
insolation.description: The energy received from the host star. High insolation creates volcanic surfaces, lava glow, and active atmospheres. Low insolation produces ice coverage and frozen landscapes.

starTemp.title: Star Temperature
starTemp.description: Affects the lighting color. Planets around red dwarf stars have a warm orange tint, while those orbiting hot blue stars appear cooler and bluer.

planetType.title: Planet Type
planetType.description: Determines the base shader: Gas Giants show banded atmospheres with storms, Ice Giants have smooth blue-green methane atmospheres, and Rocky planets display terrain, craters, and possible atmospheres.

visualization.disclaimer: Note: These visualizations are artistic interpretations based on scientific data, not actual photographs. Each planet's unique seed ensures consistent appearance across sessions.

reviews.placeholder: Reviews coming soon! Share your thoughts about this distant world.

methodology.title: Scoring Methodology
methodology.description: Our habitability score (0-100) is calculated from four key factors:
methodology.temperature: Temperature (40 pts): Ideal range 200-320K for liquid water
methodology.size: Size (30 pts): Earth-like radius 0.8-1.5 R‚äï for rocky surface
methodology.starType: Star Type (20 pts): G-type stars score highest (stable, long-lived)
methodology.insolation: Insolation (10 pts): Energy flux 0.5-2.0 Earth's for moderate climate
